text.text: Boozer. Watering hole. The local. Ale den. The House of Hangover. There are many nicknames we give our favourite drinking establishments and London benefits from some of the best community drinking spots in this fair land. But this time we're not talking about sleepy hideaways of fire-lit backrooms, because us Londoners like to party with our pie and pints. From late-night Hackney hangouts to Brixton staples, ditch the club and let loose at your local.

tip.text:
Found down a narrow-ish street amongst the bustle of Hackney lies The Gun, everything you want your local boozer to be and more. In some form or another the pub itself has been serving pints of the good stuff for Hackney patrons since 1860, but in its latest guise The Gun offers hearty food, locally sourced ales and spirits, arguably the city's greatest pub quiz, and some of the best pub dogs to stroke in all of LDN.

They also welcome a weekly rotation of some of London's finest DJ talent all in the confines of a cozy east end drinkery; with DJs spinning from Thursday to Sunday and dancing heavily encouraged. From tropical disco for your end of week celebration to Sunday selections to calm your soul, The Gun offers a night on the tiles without taking a big knock to your bank balance.

text.text: In some form or another The Gun has been serving pints of the good stuff for Hackney patrons since 1860, but in its latest guise The Gun offers hearty food, locally sourced ales and spirits, arguably the city's greatest pub quiz, and some of the best pub dogs to stroke in all of LDN. They also welcome a weekly rotation of some of London's finest DJ talent, all in the confines of a cozy east end drinkery; with DJs spinning from Thursday to Sunday and dancing heavily encouraged.

tip.text:
This isn't your sleepy, 'nurse a pint for an hour in front of a roaring fire' village pub. The preferred local for many a Goldsmiths student intent on getting drunker than Shane MacGowan on St. Patrick's Day, The Amersham Arms is home to many a best night you won't remember.

Mondays play host to a near-legendary comedy night welcoming many famous stand-ups; while the weekends are all about live bands and DJs playing until the wee hours, spanning everything from mosh pit friendly punk shows to reggae roots until 3am. For cheap thrills and drink spills, Amersham is the one.

text.text: This isn't your sleepy, 'nurse a pint for an hour in front of a roaring fire' village pub.  The Amersham Arms is home to many a best night you will never remember, with Mondays playing host to a near-legendary comedy night, while weekends are all about live bands and DJs playing until the wee hours. Spanning everything from mosh pit friendly punk shows to reggae roots until 3am - for cheap thrills and drink spills, Amersham is the one.

tip.text:
Like your mum at a wedding, The Shacklewell Arms is a beautiful, sweaty mess - and we love her for it. From peeling astroturf in the graffitied garden and dripping taps in the rank toilets; to the noisy pub in the front and the humid, low-ceilinged event space in the back, the place exudes scruffy charm with only the smallest helping of pretension. It rocks and it rolls and occasionally it does both at once.

It’s run by the minds that bring us Field Day every year, so you’ll often catch up-and-coming acts that, in a couple of years when they blow, you can say you saw in a dingy Hackney pub - which is just the boost your rapidly dwindling stock of social capital could use.

text.text: The Shacklewell Arms is an east London staple, no different than The Kray Twins or the bearded hipster. From peeling wallpaper to dusty leather booths and rank toilets, The Shacklewell Arms exudes scruffy charm. On weekends you'll find the very best of era-spanning indie in DANCE YRSELF CLEAN to bass heavy hip-hop in Juicy, keeping the energy going and the pints of ale flowing until 3am. Long live The Shacklewell Arms, you beautiful, sweaty mess you.

tip.text:
In amongst the ever-changing face of Stoke Newington, where yummy mummies display their newborn babies with pride and every other shop sells expensive home furnishings, sometimes you just want something a little less... wanky. Cue, The Three Crowns found on the corner of Church Street. Offering meaty selections and chips and gravy for the northern natives throughout the week, punters can tuck in to one of their many local ales.

While the basement known as 'The Waiting Room' hosts a weekly selection of gigs and club events, The Three Crowns is a more relaxed affair that still packs a punch for party-goers. Head down on a Friday or Saturday and you'll find a packed pub dancing to classic disco cuts or R&B bangers - think Ashanti and Missy Elliot crossed with Prince. Table dancers welcome.

text.text: In amongst the ever-changing face of Stoke Newington lies The Three Crowns. While the basement known as 'The Waiting Room' hosts a weekly selection of gigs and club events, The Three Crowns is a more relaxed affair that still packs a punch for party goers. Head down on a Friday or Saturday and you'll find a packed pub dancing to classic disco cuts or R&B bangers - think Ashanti and Missy Elliot crossed with Prince. Table dancers welcome.

tip.text:
Dogstar has many a hangover on its hands and it's easy to see why. With a 4am weekend license, a weekly selection of stellar club nights and an always-up-for-it crowd, its become renowned for basically being the last-stop on any wild night out in this patch of South.

Look beyond that and you'll find your typically average stone baked pizzas, pool tables and cocktails. But lets be frank - this place is about the late night dancing. This three-floor, sprawling 20-year-old pub (and London's first DJ pub) has become a Brixton staple, fuelling many a dancefloor romance along the way.

text.text: Fact; Dogstar is responsible for the largest amount of hangovers in all the city and it's easy to see why. With a 4am license, a weekly selection of stellar club nights and an always-up-for-it crowd, Dogstar have become renowned for making your Sunday mornings unbearable. This three-floor, sprawling 20-year-old pub has become a Brixton staple, fuelling many a dancefloor romance along the way.

tip.text:
Farr's treads a distinct line between charming local boozer, staple Sunday afternoon spot and antiques emporium. Old telephone boxes, vintage record players, trombones, hairdresser chairs and whatever form of bric-a-brac you can imagine decorates every nook & cranny in this Dalston cornerstone.

But what about the booze? Thankfully, Farr's offers both style and substance as thirsty travellers can expect ales and IPAs from east London's favourite boozers and an extensive cocktail selection to boot. Foodies can indulge in their hearty selection of burgers, buns and Sunday roasts, while for the pub ravers DJs spin every Saturday from 8pm - 1am on their vinyl-only setup. Come for the decor, stay for the tunes, leave with no regrets... until the next morning, that is.

text.text: Farr's treads a distinct line between charming local boozer, staple Sunday afternoon spot and antique's emporium. Old telephone boxes and vintage record players decorate every nook & cranny in this Dalston cornerstone. Foodies can indulge in their hearty selection of burgers, buns and Sunday roasts, while for the pub ravers DJs spin every Saturday from 8pm - 1am on their vinyl-only setup. Come for the decor, stay for the tunes, leave with no regrets... until the next morning, that is.

tip.text:
Named after a Dutchman who once flew, this venue plays a special role on the queer and alternative scene, and offers some of the weirdest shit you've ever seen. It's no wonder, with a two floor venue, a 6am licence, a free exhibition space and a fit-for-purpose basement-dungeon to hire, you can pretty much organise anything you like. And people do - from fetish nights, to psychedelic trans clubs, shocking live performances, shibari workshops, intriguing exhibitions and alternative drag shows, the only limitation is your imagination.

The venue is only open for events. It's also up for hire, simply drop them an email to find out more.

text.text: Named after a Dutchman who once flew, this spot offers some of the weirdest shit you've ever seen. It's no wonder, with a two floor venue, a 6am licence, a free exhibition space and a fit-for-purpose basement-dungeon to hire, you can pretty much organise anything you like. And people do - from fetish nights, to psychedelic trans clubs, shocking live performances, shibari workshops, intriguing exhibitions and alternative drag shows.

tip.text:
There ain't no party quite like a Victoria party. Away from the charming, vomit-laden streets of Dalston Kingsland lies weekend favourite, The Victoria, a typical east end boozer with a difference. Offering the staple hangover-friendly meals of burgers, fries, hot dogs and other meaty essentials, behind a book case at the back of the pub lies one of London's most underrated venues; hosting live performances and free club nights most days of the week.

Owned by The Jaguar Shoes Collective, The Victoria is a vital staple for those in search of no frills attached fun, the type of place where one pint can easily turn into 6 or 7 before you've had chance to think 'how hungover will this make me tomorrow?' The answer is very... very hungover.

text.text: There ain't no party quite like a Victoria party. Away from the charming, vomit-laden streets of Dalston Kingsland lies weekend favourite, The Victoria, a typical east end boozer with a difference. Offering the staple hangover-friendly meals of burgers, fries, hot dogs and other meaty essentials, behind a book case at the back of the pub lies one of London's most underrated venues; hosting live performances and free club nights most days of the week.

tip.text:
Effra Social wasn't always the tucked away nightspot of choice for many a Brixton local and pub raver. Once upon a time, it was a Conservative social club, where Tories gathered for over 100 years to discuss right-wing politics over pints of beer and cocktails made from the tears of the poor... maybe.

But now, Effra is one of south London's most unique hotspots for late-night dancing, and whatever you think of their policies, the Tories can build a bloody good building. Part-working men's club complete with gloriously tacky decor, head down there on a weekend to find DJs spinning disco classics and guilty pleasures, or simply get lost in the many, many hidden rooms that lie within its walls. Behind the stage there's a hidden restaurant too, serving pub grub staples and decent ales.

text.text: Once upon a time, Effra's was a Conservative social club, where Tories gathered for over 100 years to discuss right-wing politics over pints of beer and cocktails made from the tears of the poor. Now, Effra is one of south London's most unique hotspots for late-night dancing. Part-working men's club complete with gloriously tacky decor, head down there on a weekend to find DJs spinning disco classics and guilty pleasures.

tip.text:
Once welcoming many a Libertine and Winehouse in the glory years of Camden past, Camden Assembly has been given a new lease of life by the same team who brought us XOYO, Phonox, The Jazz Café and many other London favourite's that continue to fuel your hangovers. In the day, Americana meat-heavy dining is provided by favourites Lucky Chip who offer vital stomach lining for your all-day booze sessions.

But by night, Camden Assembly turns into your newest pub-rave spot of choice. Giving precedence to new, up-and-coming talent from across the musical spectrum - grime to techno, indie to new wave - Camden Assembly is becoming one of London's best multifaceted music spaces. Grab yourself a pint, get down there and dance.

text.text: Once welcoming many a Libertine and Winehouse in the glory years of Camden past, by day, Americana meat-heavy dining is provided by Patty Supreme who offer vital stomach lining for your all-day booze sessions. But by night, Camden Assembly turns into your newest pub-rave spot of choice. Giving precedence to new, up-and-coming talent from across the musical spectrum - grime to techno, indie to new wave - Camden Assembly is becoming one of London's best multifaceted music spaces.
